news politics matt-hancock-says-downing-street-"GMB: Matt Hancock discusses the alleged party at Downing StreetByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Dec | comments Last year’s Downing Street party is “absolutely” a matter for police to look at, Matt Hancock said today as Boris Johnson faced an outraged Tory revolt.The former Health Secretary accepted Scotland Yard was examining the Mirror’s revelations that a gathering happened in No on December .It came as Tory MPs mounted an enraged backlash over newly-revealed footage that shows No staff apparently joking about the party four days after it happened. Ex-minister Tracey Crouch said she was “fuming!” while former party chairwoman Sayeeda Warsi tweeted: Every minister, parliamentarian  staffer at the #downingstreetparty must resign NOW.” Keir Starmer accused No of spouting “lies”, while the Lib Dems demanded “any legal advice” produced on the party amid speculation it could have been legal on a technicality.As grim-faced Attorney General Suella Braverman and Health Secretary Sajid Javid were spotted going into No, Tory Tobias Ellwood urged Cabinet Secretary Simon Case or “another senior independent voice to probe the matter. Ex-No aide Dominic Cummings said the PM would need “a f***ing dead cat army” - just as reports emerged that he could announce Plan B Covid measures today.For a week after the Mirror revealed the bash on December  last year - when London was in Tier  lockdown rules - ministers have insisted no rules were broken.No even tried to insinuate it didn’t happen - by claiming whatever took place wasn’t a party.But now a clip has been leaked to ITV News of a private ‘mock’ press conference four days after the bash, which involved a Secret Santa, wine, a quiz and “ or ” people.War-gaming questionsthe event leaked, then-Press Secretary Allegra Stratton shrugged “what’s the answer ” before joking it was “was not socially distanced”.  Last night the politan Police said: We are aware of footage obtained by ITV News relating to alleged breaches of the Health Protection Regulations at a Government building in December . It is our policy not to routinely investigate retrospective breaches of the Covid- regulations, however the footage will form part of our considerations. Mr Hancock told ITV’s Good Morning Britain: “I’ve seen something from the police in the newspapers saying they will take it into consideration. It’s absolutely a matter for them and certainly not for the politicians.” But despite being in government at the time he insisted “I wasn’t invited, I wasn’t there”, adding: “I only found out about it late last night and then I got up early this morning.” Speculation has been mounting about how No claimed the party did not break rules.  Firstly, ‘permitted organised gatherings’ were allowed under the December  lawsthey happened on premises “operated by a public body” and organisers carried out a risk assessment. But at these gatherings, “mingling” between dferent household groups was still banned by law.Secondly, gatherings that were “reasonably necessary for work purposes” had an exemption under the law. But the GOV.UK Twitter account said on December , a day before the party: “Although there are exemptions for work purposes, you must not have a work Christmas lunch or party, where that is a primarily social activity.”Thirdly, barrister Adam Wagner pointed out the  Public Health Act - from which lockdown laws spawned - suggests a government department or ‘Crown property’ may have an immunity clause. The  Act says government departments can form an agreement with the local council that “any relevant provision of this Act specied in the agreement shall apply to the property”.  Mr Wagner said there are “potential legal ambiguities” and “It’s not clear whether that means it doesn’t apply to iniduals.” Tory MPs are enraged that they defended No only for the video to emerge last night. One anonymous Conservative told the BBC’s Laura Kuenssberg: “Every lie just compounds the problem. But lying eventually catches people out. “Another awful mess created out of Downing St. Question now in tea room is Boris reaching a tipping point - where he is becoming a liability and no longer an asset ” Tory MP Anne Marie Morris said: “Clearly there were rules in place that most of us were diligently followingand they decided to break them. “Itaposs not on and, at the very least, they should admit their blatant error and apologise for breaking the rules they imposed on society.”  Former minister Tracey Crouch, MP for Chatham and Aylesford, demanded an apology, Kent Online reported. I am fuming! My constituents have every right to be angry, she said. Their memories of lost loved ones are traumatised knowing that they died alone, first and last Christmases passed by, and many spent what is usually a special day by themselves. I am not even going to begin to justy or defend a party in Downing Street. We all deserve a fulsome explanation and apology and swtly.Tory peer and former Conservative Party chairwoman Sayeeda Warsi said all those present at any party should resign “no s no buts”.She added: “The rule of law is a fundamental value, the glue that hold us together as a nation. Once that is trashed by those in power the very essence of our democracy is at stake. Chairman of the Commons Education Committee and Tory MP for Harlow Robert Halfon said: I certainly think that those who were doing the video should apologise for the insensitivity of it when people were suffering and struggling all through that time.  But he stopped short of calling for the Prime Minister himself to apologise. NHS England medical director Stephen Powis told BBC Radio aposs Today: Itaposs important the public follow the guidelines, I think they have done that magnicently.Conservative Sir Roger Gale told Sky News: “This is like something out of The Thick Of It. He added: “I fear this could be a Barnard Castle moment all over again. It is very serious.”Sir Roger demanded Boris Johnson come toPMQsand either admit there was a party - or categorically deny it.The MP told the BBC: “If he says that, I will believe him. And the reason is because that will be on the record at the despatch box, and of course to mislead the House of Commons deliberately would be a resignation matter.” Failing to explain the row this morning, Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said at the Chatham House foreign affairs think tank: “We do follow the rules on Covid. “On that particular issue that you raised, I’m not aware of the precise circumstances. “I know the Prime Minister’s spokesman has addressed that issue.” She added: “It is in everybodyaposs interests that we follow the Covid rules and that we boost vaccines as soon as we practically can. “There will be steps up in the booster campaign and that is obviously very important to deal with the new iant. “As to alleged events in No, I don’t know the detail of what happened. “I know that the Prime Minister’s spokesman answered those questions in detail yesterday and I am sure there will be further discussion of that issue. “My focus has been, as I am sure imagine, on foreign policy.” The recording is of a rehearsal on December  for planned daily TV media briefings, which Ms Stratton was supposed to be the face of but the Prime Minister later scrapped. Ed Oldfield, adviser to the PM, said: “I’ve just seen reports on Twitter that there was a Downing Street Christmas party on Friday night, do you recognise those reports ” “I went home”, replies Ms Stratton, who appears to crease up laughing before telling colleagues hold on. Following a long pause, Mr Oldfield goes on: “Would the prime minister condone having a Christmas party ” Ms Stratton laughs and says “what’s the answer  before her colleagues step in to help her compose an answer. “It wasn’t a party, it was cheese and wine”, offers one. On the day of the party, Tier  rules banned gatherings of multiple households in London unless they were “permitted organised gatherings” such as a business meeting. Less than  hours after the No party, Boris Johnson told England that with a heavy heart, Christmas would not be able to go ahead as planned. On the day of the mock press conference,  people died in the UK with Covid on their death certicate.Boris Johnson’s government went into hiding this morning as Health Secretary Sajid Javid abandoned the ‘broadcast round’ of TV interviews, where he was meant to celebrate a year since the first Covid jab. ITV’s Good Morning Britain left an empty chair while BBC Radio  presenter Nick Robinson said Mr Javid’s appearances was cancelled “just a few minutes after that video emerged”.Last night No bizarrely claimed in response to the evidence: “There was no Christmas party. title: metro mayors back test veterans
story: mayors back "truth and justice" for Cold War nuclear heroesPolitical heavyweights have demanded the Prime Minister meet veterans of atomic testing in their decades-long fight for recognitionBySusie Bonace:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec  mayors representing a third of Britain’s population have backed a medal and compensation for the country’s nuclear test veterans.The Labour heavyweights, led by Greater Manchester’s Andy Burnham, Liverpool’s Steve Rotheram, and South Yorkshire’s Dan Jarvis, have demanded “truth and justice” for the victims of Cold War radiation experiments. And they have thrown their weight behind the Mirror’s Look Me In The Eye campaign, which recently saw Prime Minister Boris Johnson agree to become the first premier to sit down and meet with survivors and their families. Official numbers are patchy but it is thought around , men, many of them on National Service, took part in hundreds of nuclear blasts in America, Australia and the South Pacic between  and . They now report a legacy of rare cancers, a higher risk of miscarriages for their wives, and  times the usual rate of birth defects in their children. Genetic research has proved they have the same level of DNA damage as clean-up workers at Chernobyl. After the Mirror won them a medal review, last year they were told there was not enough “risk and rigour” in the tests to get a gong.In a joint statement, the mayors said: “It is impossible to comprehend the risk taken by our nuclear test veterans. They served on the most dangerous of operations thousands of miles from home, where they were exposed to le-threatening levels of radiation.” Read more The eight mayors - also including Tracy Brabin of West Yorkshire, Jamie Driscoll of North of Tyne, Dr Nik Johnson of Cambridgeshire and Peterborough, Sadiq Khan of London, and Dan Norris of the West of England - represent a total of m Brits. They said: The government has a moral duty to recognise the sacrices our veterans have made, and support them to live dignied and fulfilled lives once they leave the Armed Forces. Despite their dedication, this government is failing our nuclear test veterans and their families. The government has denied them the opportunities they deserve and refused to give any compensation for the medical conditions that have dominated their lives.  They added: “Time is running out for us to do the right thing. We’re backing the ‘Look Me In The Eye’ campaign and calling on the PM to meet with these brave veterans, recognise their sacrices, provide compensation where it is due, and award them the medal they rightly deserve. We need truth and justice for our nuclear test veterans.”The Ministry of Defence refuses to reveal how many nuclear test veterans have qualied for a war pension on the basis of radiation injury, but the Mirror has uncovered cases of veterans forced to leave their deathbeds for hearings, asked to provide proof of their doses, and even labelled aposvexatiousapos for making repeated Freedom of Information requests for their records.Information gathered by the British Nuclear Test Veteransapos Association in  found that, of , pension applications, .% were refused outright. After appeals, only  were approved, a success rate of just .%.Last year, then-Veterans Minister Johnny Mercer said there was hostility towards this group of veterans among officials and it had to change. In , the MoD finally admitted that, contrary to what it had told them for decades, % of the men were probably exposed to radiation when ordered to fly through mushroom clouds, sail and crawl through fallout, and decontaminate equipment. But successive governments have consistently refused formal compensation, and spent millions fighting legal claims. Some servicemen died at the time of the tests, or soon after.In , David Cameron thanked test veterans for their service and made charitable funding available for memorials, archives, and home adaptations, but stopped short of full, official recognition. In , Labour promised each veteran a £, ex gratia payment, and this summer Keir Starmer told them that was just the starting point of what he would do in government. He said: “Your campaign is our campaign.”For more than  years the Mirror has campaigned for justice for the brave men who took part in Britain’s nuclear weapons tests. The Ministry of Defence has fought back every step of the way. We have told countless heartbreaking stories of grieving mums, children with deformities, men aged before their time and widows struggling to hold their families together, all while campaigning for recognition. Two years ago we launched an appeal for a medal for the , survivors. For the first time we were able to prove some were unwittingly used in experiments. Our appeal was backed by then-Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson but his review foundered after he lost his job. It had only six meetings in two years. They never asked to meet veterans. They never questioned the evidence. Instead they asked for information from the MoD, which has a track record of denying what its own paperwork later proves. And as our medal campaign gathered steam, civil servants simultaneously withdrew public documents from the National Archives. Would anyone working in Whitehall today stay there, megatons of plutonium exploded south of the river  The test veterans and their families will never stop fighting. The Mirror will never cease to demand they are heard. Prime Minister, listen to them. title: no 10 noel idea lead
story: No  has Noel idea and it may lead to an unhappy New Year - Voice of the MirrorContinued contradictory messages from a rule-breaking Prime Minister on both parties and socialising is heightening concern as the coronavirus spreads, including an Omicron iant worrying virologistsBoris Johnson is making a big gamble with his Christmas plans Image: PAopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsIf we enjoy a merry Christmas, we may be faced with an unhappy New Year – a warning that none of us wanted to hear. The words yesterday from Cambridge University statistician Prof Sir David Spiegelhalter rang alarm bells about the potential impact of Christmas socialising. Continued contradictory messages from a rule-breaking Prime Minister on both parties and socialising is heightening concern as the coronavirus spreads, including an Omicron iant worrying virologists. And when vaccines are the main line of Britain’s defence in this pandemic, Boris Johnson’s failure to mobilise a national jabbing programme to match the huge effort earlier this year is a lethal and expensive blunder. Statistics released by Labour leader Keir Starmer, showing , doses in a recent -hour period were less than half the , in a day at the peak last March, damn a frequently complacent and dithering No . More suffering The killing of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes demands a national review to protect other children from evil crimes – but regrettably there is no certainty other little innocents will not lose their lives. We heard that from Government ministers after Victoria Climbie, Baby P – Peter Connolly, Daniel Pelka and now Arthur that lessons must be learned and perhaps some were. Yet children continue to die after facing the most horric and unthinkable cruelty. Increasing already y prison sentences may assuage public anger and deliver what many would applaud as tougher justice. What does not exist is evidence the prospect of extra years in prison would deter depraved adults. Strictly Dan-go It was probably time for Dan Walker to foxtrot off Strictly – after doing so well to reach the show’s quarter final. news politics no--staff-filmed-joking-"Staff joke about Downing Street Christmas party during lockdownByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsSenior Downing Street staff cracked jokes about a rule-breaking Christmas party at No  just four days after it was alleged to have taken place, a bombshell leaked recording reveals. Officials can be heard laughing about cheese and wine as Boris Johnsonaposs former spokeswoman Allegra Stratton cracked jokes about a business meeting in which there was “definitely no social distancing.” The recording, passed to ITV News, is of a rehearsal on December  for planned daily TV media briefings, which Ms Stratton was supposed to be the face of but the Prime Minister later scrapped. Staff in the  Downing Street press room can be heard pretending to ask questions about a party. Boris Johnson has faced calls to resign while Labour leader Keir Starmer said he must come clean about it.Meanwhile the politan Police says it is reviewing the footage and it will form part of its considerations.Ed Oldfield, adviser to the PM, said: “I’ve just seen reports on Twitter that there was a Downing Street Christmas party on Friday night, do you recognise those reports ”  “I went home”, replies Ms Stratton, who appears to crease up laughing before telling colleagues hold on. Following a long pause, Mr Oldfield goes on: “Would the prime minister condone having a Christmas party ” Ms Stratton laughs and says “what’s the answer  before her colleagues step in to help her compose an answer. “It wasn’t a party, it was cheese and wine”, offers one. “Is cheese and wine alright ” Ms Stratton asks, before adding, again laughing “it was a business meeting”. She then warns those present “this is recorded” and says “this fictional party was a business meeting and it was not socially distanced.”  Downing Street has denied there was a party and, when asked himself, the Prime Minister said he had been assured guidance was followed. It comes after the Daily Mirror revealed bombshell allegations that revellers at an unofficial No Christmas bash on December  allegedly enjoyed food, drinks and games which went on well past midnight. Fresh allegations in the Times also revealed that officials organised a apossecret Santaapos and sent out invites, suggesting the event was planned. Millions of people were living under strict Covid rules at the time - with London under Tier  restrictions.  The following day Mr Johnson announced that Christmas plans had to be drastically scaled back. Keir Starmer, leader of the Labour Party, said: “People across the country followed the rules even when that meant being separated from their families, locked down and - tragically for many - unable to say goodbye to their loved ones. “They had a right to expect that the government was doing the same. To lie and to laugh about those lies is shameful. “The Prime Minister now needs to come clean, and apologise. It cannot be one rule for the Conservatives and another for everyone .”  The SNPaposs Westminster leader Ian Blackford said: This video is damning and leaves the Prime Minister with a lot to answer for. When every inidual up and down the country was told to stay at home in order to protect the NHS, the Tories were instead having a Christmas party which, as a senior staff member has now confirmed, was aposnot socially distancedapos.If this is true, then the Prime Ministeraposs position is untenable and he must remove himself from office immediately. Ms Stratton remains the Prime Ministeraposs spokeswoman on Cop and had previously worked as head of communications for Chancellor Rishi Sunak.The Chancellor was pressed on whether he or any of his special advisers had attended the Christmas parties in Downing Street last year.He told MPs: No, I did not attend any parties.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonPoliticsChristmas partyDowning Street Christmas Party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: not vaccinating primary school kids
story: Not vaccinating primary school kids is scandalous negligence - parents deserve choicePrimary school age children in the US, Australia and some European countries are getting jabbed, so why not here  Some parents won’t want their kids to be vaccinated but I do, desperately. So where’s MY choice It is estimated by a charity that , children have long CovidImage: Getty Images iStockphotoopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Dec | commentsAt first it seemed sensible. Then insulting. Now  Scandalously negligent. Primary school age children in this country currently have the highest infection rates they’ve ever had during the pandemic - but there are no plans to start vaccinating them. Nearly five million - year olds have been jabbed in America, on Sunday the scheme was approved in Australia, and the rollout is expected to start next week in some European countries after it was given the green light by the European Medicines Agency. But here, nothing.Some parents won’t want their kids to be vaccinated of course, and that’s their choice - but I do, desperately. So where’s MY choice I’d take my seven-year-old to a back street illegal vaccinatorsuch a thing existed, but unfortunately it doesn’t.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section Omicron is only just getting started, and already a whopping , kids tested positive for covid last week, with actual infection levels estimated to be up to four times higher than that. Charity Long Covid Kids reports that , children currently have long covid - , of whom have been suffering with it for over a year.Respected epidemiologist and public health researcher Deepti Gurdasani puts it simply, “Infection of children with SARS-Cov- will be one of those actions we look back at in history and wonder how on earth it was allowed to happen - by those who should’ve been protecting them.” I’ve gratefully accepted every vaccine my son has been offered, starting when he was eight weeks old. I’m lucky to live in a country where they’re available as standard, for free. And I believe it’s my duty to ensure he’s up to date with them, in accordance with the No part of parenting: trying to keep your kid safe. Also of course in this case, where coronavirus is still circulating, jabbing everyone means the whole community is protected. It’s better for everyone. The news about Omicron is becoming ever more concerning, and there were already upwards of , Covid cases a day before it reared its unwelcome head. And yet, every morning, I deliver my son into an environment where he mixes freely with hundreds of others, with no mitigations. No masks, no bubbles, no ventilation. And no vaccine either. Best of British luck, eh, kid  Vaccinating children was approved in the US at the end of October. Prof Jon Levy, chairman of the Department of Environmental Health at Boston University, welcomed the news: “Every paediatrician I know is eager to get their own kids age - vaccinated immediately. “They plan to get as many kids vaccinated in their offices as quickly as possible. If that doesn’t tell you how safe and effective the vaccine is. I don’t know what will.” If the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation know something we don’t – and have good reason why they’re dragging their feet on protecting the smallest, most helpless people in our communities – they need to speak up. Otherwise, they’re forcing us to fail our children. title: top foreign office civil servant
story: Top Foreign Office civil servant slammed for staying on holiday almost  weeks after Kabul fellPermanent secretary Sir Philip Barton remained on his break even after former Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab jetted back from CreteThe Foreign Offices top civil servant, Sir Philip Barton, giving evidence on the evacuation from Afghanistan Image: PAByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThe Foreign Officeaposs top civil servant faced a barrage of criticism after admitting he stayed on his summer holiday for almost two weeks after Afghanistan fell to to the Taliban.Permanent secretary Sir Philip Barton was blasted for being away in the UK and abroad as the Taliban overran the war-torn nation in August. He revealed that he was on leave from August  and did notuntil August , some  days after the Afghan government collapsed.He told the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee: “If I had my time again I would have come back from my leave earlier than I did.” Sir Philip was criticised by MPs for failing to come back from holidays to deal with the crisis.He even chose to remain on holiday after then-Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab jetted home from a luxury break in Crete.Conservative MP Alicia Kearns told Sir Philip: I donapost think it is enough to say, aposmea culpaapos. How in two weeks did at no point, you go, aposI canapost, I have to go in and protect my people’ ”  The civil servant said cover arrangements were in place and he stayed in touch with the department all the way through the period. He also defended ordering crisis centre workers to stick to eight-hour shts - despite a “monumental volume” of emails from desperate Afghans and Britons hoping to flee. Tory MP Bob Seely said: “People clocking off after eight hours, not bothering to come in at weekends - it’s all complacent and wooly and waffly and unfocused and sort of just a bit rubbish.” But Sir Philip hit back: “There isn’t a clocking off culture at all … when we’re in a full blown crisis it’s very intense. “We have an eight-hour sht system and we make sure therefore that people are getting a period of rest and then coming back onto shts.” MPs also heard explosive claims from Raphael Marshall, who worked for the Foreign Office during Operation Pitting and who branded the ministry’s response to the Afghan crisis dysal and chaotic. Allied forces withdrew as Taliban fighters advanced - sparking a refugee emergency as worried Afghans tried to flee Mr Marshall claimed just % of Afghan nationals who applied to leave under one UK scheme received help. Some were murdered after being left in Kabul after the Taliban swept to power, he alleged in written evidence to the committee. Meanwhile, a row broke out over claims the PM intervened to order the rescue of animals from Afghanistan after the Taliban takeover. Sir Philip insisted there was was no prioritisation of animals in the evacuation from Kabul, after a whistleblower claimed Boris Johnson issued an instruction to save animals from the Nowzad shelter during the evacuation effort.Whistleblower Mr Marshall accused Mr Johnson of issuing an instruction to save animals from the Nowzad shelter - potentially putting British troopsapos lives at risk and preventing people from fleeing Kabul. He told MPs there was an instruction from the Prime Minister to use considerable capacity to transport Nowzadaposs animals. Mr Johnson branded the claim complete nonsense and Downing Street said it was entirely untrue. Former Royal Marine Paul Pen Farthing, who ran the shelter, launched a high-profile campaign to get his staff and animals out, using a plane funded through donations. The Government sponsored clearance for the charter flight - triggering allegations animals had been prioritised over people. It has previously been claimed the PM’s we Carrie also intervened to ensure the animals were transported to the UK. But Mr Johnson’s spokesman said neither the Prime Minister nor Mrs Johnson were involved. Yet campaigner Dominic Dyer insisted he had called on the Johnsons for help.I forced the Prime Ministeraposs arm, I think all of us behind this campaign did,” he told the BBC. The next day, the senior commander in the Ministry of Defence, in the Air Force department, contacted me and said you can have your flight authorisation and we could get that plane down on the ground into Afghanistan.“Thataposs my proof because without the intervention from the Prime Minister,would have continued to block the operation. Labour leader Keir Starmer said of Mr Marshall’s evidence: “This is a devastating testimony that lays bare the shambolic incompetence of the Government in protecting thousands of Afghans to whom we owed a duty.”Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonBen WallaceLabour PartyConservative PartyTalibanForeign OfficeAir ForceBBCMinistry of DefenceCivil servantsPublic servicesPoliticsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. commentsBoris Johnson’s government went into hiding this morning after the PM was disgraced by footage of his own team laughing about a No staff Christmas party.For a week after the Mirror revealed the bash on December  last year - when London was in Tier  lockdown rules - ministers have insisted no rules were broken.No even brazenly tried to insinuate it didn’t happen - by claiming whatever took place wasn’t a party.But now a clip has been leaked to ITV News of a private ‘mock’ press conference four days after the bash, which involved a Secret Santa, wine, a quiz and “ or ” people.War-gaming questionsthe event leaked, then-Press Secretary Allegra Stratton shrugged “what’s the answer ” before joking it was “was not socially distanced”. Staff in the £.m No briefing room joked about there being “cheese and wine” and suggested they could defend it as a “business meeting”.  On the day of the mock press conference,  people died in the UK with Covid on their death certicate. Boris Johnson is not accused of being at the December  party, but is accused of being at a second bash held as a leaving do on November . Today Health Secretary Sajid Javid abandoned the ‘broadcast round’ of morning TV interviews, where he was meant to celebrate a year since the first Covid jab. ITV’s Good Morning Britain left an empty chair while BBC Radio  presenter Nick Robinson said Mr Javid’s appearances was cancelled “just a few minutes after that video emerged”.It is incredibly rare for the government to put no minister on the morning round, which happens between am and am and often involves five or six interviews.  Sky News presenter Joe Pike said: “The Health Secretary was briefly due to come on this programme and other programmes this morning because it’s one year since Margaret Keenan was the first person in the world to receive a Covid vaccine outside a clinical trials. “That was cancelled, and other ministerial visits today with media access have also been cancelled.” Last night No bizarrely claimed in response to the evidence: “There was no Christmas party. COVID rules have been followed at all times.”But the PM will have to face the music at Prime Minister’s Questions at noon, where Keir Starmer is likely to blast his attempts to deceive the British public. Labour ’s leader said “to lie and to laugh about those lies is shameful,” adding: “Unfortunately we have a Prime Minister who is socially distanced from the truth.”SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford added: “If this is true, then the Prime Minister’s position is untenable and he must remove himself from office immediately.”Tory MPs are privately enraged that they defended No only for Boris Johnson to breach their trust. One told ITV there would need to be resignations.  Conservative Sir Roger Gale told Sky News: “This is like something out of The Thick Of It. He added: “I fear this could be a Barnard Castle moment all over again. It is very serious.” Sir Roger demanded Boris Johnson come to PMQs and either admit there was a party - or categorically deny it. The MP told the BBC: “If he says that, I will believe him. And the reason is because that will be on the record at the despatch box, and of course to mislead the House of Commons deliberately would be a resignation matter.” On the day of the party, Tier  rules banned gatherings of multiple households in London unless they were “permitted organised gatherings” such as a business meeting. But barely  hours before staff met, the government explicitly warned a business owner that Christmas drinks would not count as “reasonably necessary for work”.The GOV.UK Twitter account told a man called Mick on December : “Although there are exemptions for work purposes, you must not have a work Christmas lunch or party, where that is a primarily social activity and is not otherwise permitted by the rules in your tier.” NHS Confederation chief Matthew Taylor said the Downing Street Christmas party was a “blow to morale” to NHS staff. “If it feels as though powerful people are not playing by the rules, then there is a blow to morale, it does make it harder to get people to follow the advice,” he added.One NHS staffer told the PA Media news agency she was incandescent with anger.To say Iaposm angry... Iaposm incandescent. Itaposs the disrespect, itaposs the one rule for us and another rule for them, thataposs whataposs the worst, the NHS worker said. I see Allegra Stratton laughing up there and I feel sick, I feel disrespected,Iaposve been taken for a mug. I canapost put enough words together right now as to how appalling that behaviour is. It should have consequences.  Former Health Secretary Matt Hancock said it was “absolutely” a matter for police to look at. Last night the politan Police said: We are aware of footage obtained by ITV News relating to alleged breaches of the Health Protection Regulations at a Government building in December . It is our policy not to routinely investigate retrospective breaches of the Covid- regulations, however the footage will form part of our considerations. Mr Hancock told Good Morning Britain: “I’ve seen something from the police in the newspapers saying they will take it into consideration. It’s absolutely a matter for them and certainly not for the politicians.” But despite being in government at the time he insisted “I wasn’t invited, I wasn’t there”, adding: “I only found out about it late last night and then I got up early this morning.” The recording is of a rehearsal on December  for planned daily TV media briefings, which Ms Stratton was supposed to be the face of but the Prime Minister later scrapped.  Ed Oldfield, adviser to the PM, said: “I’ve just seen reports on Twitter that there was a Downing Street Christmas party on Friday night, do you recognise those reports ” “I went home”, replies Ms Stratton, who appears to crease up laughing before telling colleagues hold on. Following a long pause, Mr Oldfield goes on: “Would the prime minister condone having a Christmas party ” Ms Stratton laughs and says “what’s the answer  before her colleagues step in to help her compose an answer. “It wasn’t a party, it was cheese and wine”, offers one. “Is cheese and wine alright ” Ms Stratton asks, before adding, again laughing “it was a business meeting”. She then warns those present “this is recorded” and says “this fictional party was a business meeting and it was not socially distanced.” Becky Kummer, spokesperson for Covid- Bereaved Families for Justice said: “In September Boris Johnson looked bereaved families in the eyes and told them he had done everything he could to save their loved ones. There are simply no words to describe how upsetting and shameful it is then to hear Boris Johnsonaposs team laughing about breaking the rules they had made, whilst others followed them and could only say goodbye to their loved ones through a screen. “It’s the behaviour of people who think they’re above us.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyNick RobinsonBoris JohnsonPMQsGood Morning BritainPoliticsChristmas partyDowning Street Christmas Party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: bear grylls moving words fitness
story: Exclusive: Bear Grylls moving words for fitness fanatic teen who survived brain tumour aged A call from Bear Grylls was the icing on the cake for -year-old Darshan McGregor whose wish for gym kit was granted by charity Make-A-Wish UK, backed by the Mirror Christmas AppealWeight to go Darshan McGregor! Image: CollectByNaimah Archibald-PowellJunior Feature Writer:,  Dec | commentsGetting a delivery of weights and home gym equipment was a dream come true for teen fitness fanatic Darshan McGregor. And after coming through gruelling treatment for a brain tumour, a call from Bear Grylls was the icing on the cake for the -year-old. Darshan said: “He’s been through so many le-threatening challenges so he could relate to me. Bear just said keep going, keep fighting and never give up.”Darshan’s wish for gym kit was granted by charity Make-A-Wish UK, backed by the Mirror Christmas Appeal. He says: “It’s been amazing what they’ve been able to do. “It’s really made me happy and it’s one of the things that got me through my treatments, it was one thing I thought about – ‘ I get through this, I’ll get my wish’.” It was just over four-and-a-half years ago that the youngster from Berkhamsted, Herts, was told he had a brain tumour, at the age of nine.  Darshan says: “I feel like I lost part of my childhood – I couldn’t have fun because I was constantly in hospital. It was impossible to be happy.” Mum Samreen, , said: “Because the tumour was in the thalamus, right in the middle of the brain, taking a biopsy or doing any intervention to try to release the fluid in his brain was very high risk. The process was awful.” By Jason Beattie For the majority of families this Christmas will be a joyous time of presents, food and fun. But for some children the festive season will be very dferent. Across the country there are more than , young people who are critically ill. Many will be spending what should be a special time of the year in hospital. Others will have to have treatment, scans or blood tests. With your help we can give them a Christmas that they will always remember. This year’s Mirror Christmas Appeal is raising funds for Make-A-Wish UK that helps seriously ill young people make their dreams come true.It could be they want to meet their hero or heroine or feed an animal at the zoo or travel to see Santa in Lapland. The money raised could help Joshua, six, who has severe epilepsy, achieve his wish of a bedroom makeover or Summer, also six, who has acute leukaemia and dreams of a bouncy castle. Each year Make-A-Wish helps hundreds of critically ill children achieve their letime’s ambition. But to make a wish come true takes an army of volunteers, supporters and donors. That’s why every penny you donate could make a dference. Granting a wish can transform a child’s le. It gives them something to look forward to. For others it provides a special memory which makes the treatment they need more bearable.It can also help their parents who, despite doing everything they can for their sick child, feel it is not enough. Jason Suckley, Make-A-Wish UK chief executive, said: “I met the family of a boy who was recovering from brain surgery. “His grandmother told me how dficult it had been for her to watch her daughter struggle with the challenges of her son’s condition.But while they were enjoying his wish together, her daughter turned to her and said, ‘There is still magic in this world isn’t there mum ’ . “That’s just one instance that illustrates how the power of a wish lies in sharing positive memories with loved ones. “Every donation from Mirror readers will help us create those memories – bringing joy to ill children and their families during the darkest of times.” Samreen and marketing exec dad Fraser, , consulted experts and decided proton beam therapy in the US was the way to go – but it cost more than £,. A plea for government funding was turned down, so they raised it themselves by remortgaging their home and setting up a Go Fund Me page. After chemotherapy in the UK they went to Boston for the beam therapy and radiotherapy, and by October  Darshan was cancer-free. title: boy 7 only months live
story: Boy, , may have only months to live with race on to find bone marrow transplantOlcan Wilkes has developed aplastic anaemia and his parents Sam and Genevieve of Newent, Gloucester, are urging everyone to register as a donor to give him a chance of having a le-saving bone marrow opOlcan, seven, with four-year-old Hunter Image: ©Matt MackeyByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Dec | commentsA little boy is in desperate need of a lesaving bone marrow ­transplant after being diagnosed with a rare blood disorder. Olcan Wilkes, seven, may have months to live after developing aplastic anaemia, and no current donor match available for his bone tissue type. His parents Sam and Genevieve, both , of Newent, Glos, are urging everyone to register as a donor and give their boy and others a chance. On average, % of patients with the ­condition die within a year unless a transplant is undertaken. Dad Sam said: “We need to find a bone marrow match, that’s the only cure.” Olcan is having two or three platelet transfusions a week and a blood transfusion every fortnight to keep him alive. But any small infection could hit his weakened immunity hard. Sam said: “If you aren’t on top of it, it could be ­catastrophic. The doctors have to treat everything asit’s worst-case scenario.” Olcan’s energy levels are often very low, but his parents try their best to get him outside with brother, Hunter, four.  “We take him out to the beach or wherever, places where other people aren’t around,” Sam, a farmer, said. In July, Genevieve was offered a job in Belfast and moved with her sons to Antrim, meaning Sam splits his time. It was soon after moving they noticed bruising on Olcan’s ankles. Then during a walk, he fell and his knees ­immediately turned “absolutely black and blue”. Tests in September showed he had the rare condition. Sam said he and Genevieve are amazed at how quickly he has adapted to hospital trips.  “He’s very intelligent,” Sam said. “We say you need a transplant because your blood cells need a kick up the bum.” Olcan is having immunosuppressive therapy called anti-thymocyte globulin, which could make him dependent of gruelling transfusions, and prolong his le until a donor is found. The severity of his condition means the chances of ATG working are fairly low. Sam said: “Within nine months most patients get an infection and die.”  He added as a family they are trying to raise awareness about becoming a donor. “The fact it could just happen to anyone is very upsetting,” he said.Register to be a bone marrow donor at: www.dkms.org.uk register-now Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TherapyOrgan donationParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Britain sends more than  asylum seekers back home - after taking them in as kidsThe asylum seekers arrived in Britain as lone children and were given temporary leave to remain, but sent back to Afghanistan and Iraq after their th birthdaysMigrants crossing the Channel earlier this year Image: Getty ImagesByGeraldine McKelvieInvestigations EditorMaeve McClenaghan:,  Dec Britain has sent more than  asylum seekers back to Afghanistan and Iraq over the last five years after taking them in as unaccompanied children. All were given temporary leave to remain in the UK but were ed to their country of origin after turning . The data was obtained by The Bureau of Investigative Journalism and relates to removals over the last five years. A report by the charity Refugee Support Network - now rebranded as Refugee Education UK - suggests some of those ing face perilous situations. Its researchers interviewed a range of Afghan ees for its After Return report, some of whom said they’d been caught in bombs or suicide attacks.  One, named only as Mohammed, told the charity in  that he’d been forced to join the Taliban for his own protection. He claimed he was “tortured” before leaving for the UK as a child and needed protection from his “enemies”. Then , he said: “I thought a lot about my decision, but I did not see any other way. I had to join the Taliban to be able to defend myself from my enemies and survive.” Others reported struggling with mental health issues, and accessing work and education. Under current laws, unaccompanied children arriving in the UK are expected to make asylum claims in the same way as adults - outlining exactly why ing to their home country would present a risk for them. Those rejected are granted leave to remain in the UK until six months before their th birthday.  Once this expires, children have the right to apply for an extension, but experts say very few of these applications are successful. Ben Davison, head of immigration at Ison Harrison Solicitors, said: If their appeal is unsuccessful, thataposs the point where the Home Office can take removal action. Appeals are more likely to be unsuccessful becauseitaposs going to be recognised that they will be at risk, itaposs usually recognised first time around. They can argue that they have established a private le in the UK, but there are specic rules. “Children generally need to have been in the UK for seven years to show it would be unduly harsh to remove them and those who have been here for a shorter period donapost meet that set criteria. Many are left in limbo as they wait for their claims to be processed - often housed in poorly maintained asylum accommodation. Mr Davison says that, even in light of the Taliban takeover, there is no guarantee those who arrived as unaccompanied children will be allowed to stay. He added: Itaposs not enough to simply say, aposAfghanistan has been taken overapos. It will be upon the applicant - child or adult - to make a case for why they particularly are at risk.  Our data relates to at least  asylum seekers removed from the UK between  and . It comes amid a spike in desperate asylum seekers paying traffickers to get them to the UK due to the lack of safe routes. Last month,  people drowned in the Channel while trying to reach Britain on a dinghy. A Home Office spokesman said: “Those with no right to be in the UK and foreign national offenders should be in no doubt that we will do whatever is necessary to remove them. “This is what the public rightly expects and why we regularly operate flights to dferent countries.” A foreign national offender is anyone remanded or convicted on criminal charges who does not have an absolute legal right to remain in this country. But when asked by the Mirror, the Home Office was unable to say how many,any, of the  people in question had been convicted of crimes. The spokesman added: “In light of the developing situation, we suspended s to Afghanistan in July and we do not carry out enforced s to Syria for the same reason. “We keep s under review and make assessments based on the latest country information.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON TalibanHome OfficeMental healthIraq" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: christmas jumper day what charity
story: When is Christmas Jumper Day  and what charity does it support It might still be mid-November but its safe to say we’re getting into the Christmas spirit already with internet searches for Christmas jumpers skyrocketing – just in time for Christmas Jumper Day Save the Children is asking as many people as possible to join the fun in order to raise fundsByMalvika Padin:,  Nov Updated:,  Dec | commentsChristmas Jumper Day, which has raised more than £m since its launch in , gives you a chance to dig out your festive jumpers, come together as a community and raise funds to help children and families in UK and around the world. Led by Save the Children, which works to support children and families in need all year round, the event is all the more important this year.With the pandemic impacting the charity’s funds, the organisation hopes that more people will join in the fun this year to not only spread Christmas cheer but also help raise much-needed money.  Hereaposs everything you need to know about the charitable holiday. What is Christmas Jumper Day On this day every year, the charity asks that you find your most outlandish festive jumper for one day, and donate £ -or £ for children taking part in school-to their cause.When is Christmas Jumper Day   The nationwide event always falls on the second or third Friday in December. This year it takes place on Friday, December . How to take part in Christmas Jumper Day Taking part in the holiday is easy and fun. All you need to do is come together as a community wearing your flashiest festive jumper jazzed up with jingles bells or sparkles.  Over , workplaces and . million workers have already signed up this year to spread joy on the day. To take part simply make, upcycle, borrow, swap or buy a festive sweater, wear it on Friday, December  and donate £to Save the Children. Save the Children have said that £ could help “warm some tummies, save some lives, and change the future. That’s big.” You can sign up using this form on the charity’s website. How  can you get involved  It may not always be possible for people to donate money. But the charity suggests doing ious other fun activities to either raise funds or simply get involved and spread the joy. This includes running a k, going for a bike ride or any other exercise in your jumper and getting sponsored for it. You can also make a commitment to wear your jumper for  consecutive days, no matter where you are or what you’re doing. news uk-news dog-lover-completes-gruelling--"Justice For Reggie: the campaign to end puppy farmingByCatherine Swan:,  Dec | commentsThe owner of a dog that tragically died as a result of a cruel puppy farming scam has completed a gruelling  mile trek to Downing Street in a bid to change the law on how dogs are sold. When Rick Ackers, from Wigan, North West England, bought Labrador Reggie after seeing him on a selling website, his family fell in love instantly. Rick’s then seven-year-old son became best friends with the pup. “He found love in our house,” Rick said. “He never left our side for the short time he was with us.” But just days later, the le of their newest family member was cruelly cut short after Reggie fell ill with a serious virus and had to be put to sleep.Rick was left heartbroken, and his young son tearfully asked himSanta could bring back their beloved dog. “It did cut him up,” Rick said.“I saw him talking to the ashes of Reggie on the fireplace.”  Reggie developed canine parvovirus, which was thought to be due to being taken from his mother too soon and not having his vaccinations as the seller had promised. It was later discovered that the Labrador had likely come from a puppy farm, born and raised in appalling conditions which probably contributed to his death. After Reggie died, Rick made it his mission to change the way that dogs and puppies are sold online by launching the aposJustice For Reggieapos campaign, so that other dog owners wouldn’t have to face the same heartbreak that his family had been put through. He launched a petition urging the UK Government to regulate websites where dogs are sold, by introducing new measures like verying the identity and address of sellers, and compulsory pictures of the puppies with their mothers, to help put a stop to greedy puppy farmers making quick cash.  After the petition shot up to over , signatures from fellow animal lovers, the issue is set to be debated by MPs in Parliament on December . It’s hoped that they will agree to bring in these new measures - known as Reggie’s Law, in honour of Rick’s beloved puppy. Rick planned a gruelling -mile walk from his home in Wigan all the way to London to hand-deliver the successful petition to Number . The inspiring journey aimed to raise money for Hope Rescue, a charity that saves stray and abandoned dogs in South Wales. Rick finally arrived on Tuesday afternoon and was joined by dozens of dog lovers for the final stages of the gruelling trip. Rick was pushed to the limits on the trek, and was even hospitalised after the skin on his feet wore away and developed an infection. He managed to walk an incredible  miles before being medically advised to rest by doctors. While Rick admits that he has been “suffering to the max” on his walk, he adds that, “nothing comes close to what Reggie and others have felt. He said that thinking of Reggie kept him going on his emotional journey, and he believes that the puppy will be looking down with pride at the campaign that has taken place in his name. We will change the law, he vows. title: driver refuses help dying man
story: Driver refuses to help dying man pleading for lt after falling ill on way homeRyan Craney, , tragically passed away after falling unwell while walking to a friends house and his heartbroken family are now urging people to help others in needRyan Craney died after falling ill in the street Image: Glasgow Live WSByHolly Lennon:,  Dec | commentsThe family of a young man who died suddenly after being taken unwell have criticised a driver who refused to stop and help him.Ryan Craney was walking to a friendaposs house through Germiston in Glasgow at around pm on November  when he started experiencing pains in his chest, Glasgow Live reports.The -year-old stopped a passing car to ask for help, but was refused and had to walk the rest of the distance home to Springburn alone and in pain. After arriving, Ryanaposs mum Margaret helped him to bed where he believed his chest pain was easing off - but just a few minutes later, he died. Despite paramedicsapos best efforts, his le couldnapost be saved. His cause of death will be confirmed in a post mortem later this week. His cousin Shannon explained: Ryan was at the blind tunnel at Darnick Street when he got pains in his chest. He then asked a passerby in a car for help and they refused and drove away. Ryan continued to walk home,which is a -minute walkyou arenapost struggling, so we donapost know how long it had taken him to walk home. Ryan wasnapost the type of person to ask for help so it took him a lot to ask a stranger in a car.  Ryan was a full-time carer for his mum Margaret who is said to be lost without him. In a bid to ease some of the burdens, a fundraiser has been launched to help pay for his funeral with well-wishers so far donating more than £. Shannon and the family are now urging people to be kind and help others. She added: Ryan was always smiling, always making people laugh, always the le and soul of every family event. He was so caring and would do anything for anyone. He kept himself to himself, no one has a bad word to say about him either. Ryan was also his mumaposs carer and did everything for her without even a grump. He was my aunt Margaretaposs only child, he was a healthy -year-old with no underlying health conditions. All the kids that know Ryan thought the world of him - everyone that knew Ryan loved him. He had plenty of time for anyone. A touching message on the fundraiser reads: Ryan was a great person, the most friendly guy I ever met. Always happy, a good neighbour and a better friend. He will always be remembered. Rest in peace my friend you will always be in our hearts. Margaret, we will always be at your sideyou need anything. Another added: As a mum to a mum, I just canapost imagine what you must be going through. Ryan was such a nice young man and a real tribute to you as a mum. Keep strong for him, he is watching over you. title: families split up hotels hundreds
story: Families split up in hotels hundreds of miles apart in red list quarantine chaosMinisters have been forced to double the number of rooms available as those ing from South Africa speak out about the chaos they have been faced withA quarantine hotel room near Heathrow airport Image: PAByKelly-Ann MillsReporter:,  Dec | commentsFamilies are being split up and sent hundreds of miles away from each other as the government struggles to cope with travellers ing from red list countries, reports say. Ministers have been forced to double the number of rooms available as those ing speak out about the chaos they have been faced with. One family, a mum, dad and six-year-old boy have been ripped apart after they were told the child could not share a double room with his parents. After theirfrom South Africa the mum was sent one room in Gatwick and the dad and child sent to another in Milton Keynes at a cost of more than £,. Janine Akers, the boy’s grandmother, told The Times: “They haven’t told their son yet and I don’t know what the stress is going to be when he’s told.  The hotel would not let them book for the three of them to stay [together]. When they got the two room bookings confirmed they had no choice but to take them otherwise they may have been stranded over Christmas. “This is going to cost them around £,. They had to defer their flights for £, find additional accommodation in South Africa which was £, and then pay for the quarantine hotels. Last night Olivia Blake, the couple’s MP in Sheffield, said the situation was “ridiculous” and that she was aware of other examples. She said: “Splitting families up and one parent having the full responsibility while quarantining is a big ask.  They’ve had to do it because they don’t want to be stranded for Christmas. The government needs to urgently make more family rooms available for quarantine. They did not properly fund this scheme.” John England is stuck in Pretoria, South Africa as he and his young family are unable to booked a family room for the forced -day hotel isolation. The -year-old from Hampshire told the Times that they could not confirm when they could get a family room of four, despite phoning and emailing, and aposdo not want to be split upapos. He added that his we suffers from anxiety, and aposeven quarantine will impact her signicantly. If we’re split the kids would be devastated.apos The government said: “The quarantine measures we have in place are minimising the risk of iants coming into the UK and safeguarding the hard won progress of our vaccination programme. story: GP spots unusual symptom in kids infected with concerning Omicron Covid iantAccording to Dr David Lloyd, around  per cent of children affected by early cases of Omicron have presented with an unusual rash, alongside other symptomsAround % of children who had been confirmed as having the Omicron strain had reportedly developed a rash Image: Getty ImagesByMirror:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec Parents should be aware of an unusual rash that has been linked to cases of the new Omicron Covid strain in children, a GP has said. Dr David Lloyd, a GP based in north London, has detailed the symptoms of the new iant primarily seen among younger age groups. Around % of children who have been confirmed as having the strain had reportedly developed a rash, he said. Alongside the rash were reports of symptoms including fatigue, headache and loss of appetite. According to Dr Lloyd, early cases of Omicron appeared to be presenting with slightly dferent symptoms to dferent strains.He toldSky Newsthat symptoms like fatigue, headaches and a loss of appetite seemed to be “quite important”, as was the emergence of a rash. “We’ve always had a small cohort of patients with Covid who are getting funny rashes but up to % of the Omicron children are getting an unusual rash,” he said. “So we’re starting to learn a little bit more about the virus and we are starting to look out for it.” Dr Lloyd carried on to say that the data suggested it does double “very quickly” in the number of people that were in the community. He added: “So let’s hope that it isn’t as deadly as the Delta and let’s hope that we can get on top of it. But it’s a concerning time.”Over the course of the pandemic, the NHS has listed three main symptoms of Covid to look out for in both adults and in children. The short list included a new, continuous cough, a high temperature and a loss of smell or taste. However, there had been calls for the list of symptoms to be expanded, as people with confirmed cases of Covid have reported a number of dferent symptoms. The World Health Organisationhas previously said there is no information at present to suggest the symptoms of the Omicron iant are dferent from other Covid- iants. Early data suggests that the new strain is more transmissible, but milder, than the Delta iant that is currently dominant across the world. legal team to “cancel Christmas” and prepare for a key court date in his sexual assault case. The Duke of York has instructed his legal team to “leave no stone unturned” in the lead up to the January  hearing, described as his “last ditch attempt” to get allegations he abused a teenage girl thrown out. Royal sources say he is “totally consumed” with the legal battle and has been staying up into the night to keep in constant conversation with his Calornia-based lawyers. Next Monday they are set to deliver their final submissions to the New York court before a decision is taken in the new year as to whether the Duke will face a full trial. Virginia Giuffre is pursuing Andrew through the civil courts. He is accused of “rape in the first degree” amid claims he forced Ms Giuffre, also known as Virginia Roberts, to have sex with him three times in  while she was trafficked around the world by the royal’s late paedophile pal Jeffrey Epstein.  In August she sued the Queen’s son for unspecied damages which could run into millions of poundsshe is successful. Sources close to the Duke say he has become “incredibly stressed” in recent weeks after fearing his team’s strategy of not publicly responding to the claims is failing. Insiders also suggest he is extremely worried over the financial burden he has placed on the Queen, who agreed to personally meet his spiralling court costs, which could run into millions. Prince Andrew has denied the claims. One source close to Andrew said: “The tension in the camp is palpable. No one is really sure what Andrew’s involvement is other than asking a lot of questions, but he spends his days and nights poring over documents.  “He is totally consumed by it, keeping most irregular working hours so he can be in contact with his team. “He was particularly stressed a few days ago and was heard remonstrating with one of the team. Court documents filed on behalf of her lawyers condemned Andrew, , for launching a “baseless, defamatory” attack on her credibility, character and motives. Andrew’s team must meet Monday’s deadline to file a further response before the New York district judge Lewis Kaplan rules on the next stage. The judge has said he is targeting a date for trial between October to December . Prince Andrew has hired Hollywood lawyer Andrew Brettler from the £,-an-hour firm Lavely and Singer to represent him. Meanwhile, Andrew’s former friend, socialite Ghislaine Maxwell is on trial in New York for allegedly procuring and trafficking young girls for former lover Epstein. title: omicron symptoms different traditional covid
story: Omicron symptoms dferent to previous Covid strains - the key things to look forMedics in South Africa, where the Omicron iant was first detected, are saying the main symptoms of the new iant are fatigue, body aches and a headache - and are not reflected on the NHS websitePeople walk past a Selfridges store on Oxford Street in London as Omicron cases in the UK continue to rise Image: REUTERSByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsOmicron symptoms are dferent to other strains and these are the things you should look out for.The three main symptoms of Covid- are a persistent new cough, a fever and loss of taste and smell.However, the Omicron iant aposs main symptoms are dferent as experts worry it could be dficult to detect. The current list of symptoms on the NHS website has remained unchanged since the first lockdown, even with the detection of other iants such as Delta.Medics in South Africa, where the iant was first detected, are saying the main symptoms of Omicron are fatigue, body aches and a headache. One UK expert said up to one in four colds could currently be Covid as the symptoms become more mild. Dr Angelique Coetzee, a private practitioner and chair of the South African Medical Association, said patients have not been reporting a loss of taste and smell.It comes as Covid cases in the UK are increasing and so are concerns about the Omicron iant, with an expert saying there are likely to be more than , cases of Omicron in the UK, just  days after the coronavirus was first discovered. The strain was first located in the UK in Chelmsford and Nottingham on November , , after initially detected in southern Africa.Since then, cases have been rapidly increasing across the country. Today Boris Johnson told his Cabinet that early indications show Omicron transmits more easily than the previously dominant Delta iant. Today, the total number of Omicron cases in the UK hit  as  new infections have been confirmed. This includes a further  cases in England,  in Scotland and one in Wales, according to figures from the UK Health Security Agency. It is not yet knownthe new iant increases hospital admissions or is impacted by the common vaccines.Professor Paul Hunter, from the school of medicine at the University of East Anglia, said it is spreading rather more quickly than the Delta iant. The professor told BBC Breakfast it was not clear how evidence from South Africa would translate to the UK as we have a highly vaccinated population.He added: How itaposs likely to spread in the UK still uncertain, but I think the early signs are that it will probably spread quite quickly and probably start outcompeting Delta and become the dominant iant probably within the next weeks or a month or so at least.  The big remaining question is actually how harmful it isyou do get Covid with this Omicron iant, and thataposs the question that weaposre struggling to answer at the moment. Kingaposs College Londonaposs Professor Tim Spector, who is the lead on the ZOE Symptom Tracker App, said data from the app suggests about half of all cases are being missed because people are not presenting with classic Covid symptoms. He said: Omicron is probably more, much more similar to the mild iants weaposre seeing in people who have been vaccinated with Delta than anything .  And so it is going to be producing cold-like symptoms that people wonapost recognise as Covidthey just believe the official Government advice. Speaking to Times Radio, he added: “We’re estimating that somewhere between one in three and one in four colds are actually due to Covid. “And so that’s quite a high rate of people that are currently not even bothered to get a lateral flow test, or getting a PCR test, going to parties and spreading it around.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BBCNHSKings College LondonUniversity of East AngliaPaul HunterAppsHospitalsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: prime ministers questions what time
story: Prime Ministers Questions: What time is PMQs on today and where to watch it liveBoris Johnson will face tough questions at the PMQs today after the video of No  officials joking about an alleged banned Christmas party was leaked. Heres what you need to know about Prime Ministers Questions and where you can watch it todayPMQs today will likely address Downing Street Christmas Party and Covid plan B Image: Getty ImagesByMalvika Padin:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | comments Boris Johnson is set to square off against Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer at the PMQs on Wednesday, December , as Omicron cases soar across the country, raising many concerns regarding the Covid plan B.In addition to questions about the governmentaposs alternative plan to combat rising cases, the prime minister is also likely to face tough questions about the leaked video of senior No  officials joking about a reported Christmas Party, which is alleged to have took place last year when strict Covid restrictions were in place.In the video, leaked by ITV News on Tuesday, December , , Johnson’s then-spokesperson Allegra Stratton can be seen answering practice questions at the podium of the No  Downing Street press room.According to ITV, the clip came from a rehearsal carried out on  December, just three days after one of the Christmas gatherings is alleged to have been held. Ed Oldfield, a No  adviser, is heard asking: I’ve just seen reports on Twitter that there was a Downing Street Christmas party on Friday night, do you recognise those reports ”Stratton and several other staff in the room are seen answering the question with joking answers including: It wasn’t a party, it was cheese and wine, and This fictional party was a business meeting, and it was not socially distanced. What time is PMQs today  The PMQs take place every Wednesday in the House of Commons from pm. It will run for half an hour, until the end of Question Time, ending at .pm.  Prime Ministeraposs Questions sessions typically start with a routine question from an MP about the Prime Ministeraposs engagements. This is known as an aposopen question,apos after which the MP can ask a supplementary question on any subject. Usually MPs raise particular issues of current political signicance, following which the Leader of the Opposition will ask a total of six questions about the same topic or something dferent. Where can I watch Prime Ministers Questions live The PMQs will be broadcast live on the UK Parliament YouTube channel from pm. You can also watch it on TV via BBC News and Sky News or access it online through BBC iPlayer here and the Sky News live YouTube stream. The PMQs today will be particularly crucial as no government ministers have been made available to broadcasters to defend Downing Street’s record on Wednesday morning after the video footage was leaked. We can expect to hear more about the leaked Christmas party video and the alleged Downing Street Christmas party which has caused widespread anger as well as possibly about the governmentaposs Covid plans. title: prince andrew wont join royals
story: Exclusive: Prince Andrew wont join royals for Christmas church service to keep low profileRoyal sources tell the Mirror Prince Andrew doesn’t want to be a distraction, especially as this is the first time the Queen has had her family all together since the start of the pandemic apart from at Prince Philip’s funeralPrince Andrew with his siblings at Sandringham in  Image: XByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Dec Prince Andrew will not join the royal family for the main Christmas day church service at Sandringham, after deciding to “keep a low profile” over the festive period.The Duke of York is planning to attend an early morning service at the St Mary Magdalene church on the estate, as he did a month after his catastrophic BBC Newsnight interview in .Royal sources have told how Andrew, , has “privately displayed a lot of uncertainty over Christmas” and has been “apprehensive” over joining the rest of his family at the Queen’s Norfolk home for the festive season. The Duke remains mired by sex abuse allegations that he had sex with a teenage girl on three occasions in . He has denied the claims.  A court date has been set for January  to determine whether Andrew will face a full trial in a US civil court against his accuser Virginia Giuffre.A source said: “The Duke doesn’t want to be a distraction, especially as this is the first time the Queen has had her family all together since the start of the pandemic apart from at Prince Philip ’s funeral.“Everyone is hoping to have a relaxing and joyful time.”  Sources have claimed Andrew considered hosting his daughters Eugenie and Beatrice and their families at his Royal Lodge home in Windsor, but has agreed to join the family at Sandringham after being personally asked by the Queen. Other royals including Prince Charles, the Duchess of Cornwall and the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge, are expected to join the monarch for Christmas and will attend the am service. It is hoped royal fans will be welcomed back on Christmas morning to greet the family as they make their way to the service from the Queen’s manor house. title: uk weather forecast storm barra
story: UK weather forecast: Storm Barra flood warning as rain, wind and ice cause chaosThe UK is set to be battered for a second day by Storm Barra bringing strong winds, rain and ice for much of the country and leading to widespread flood warningsThe UK is set to be battered for a second day by Storm Barra Image: Tim MerryByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsBrits are being warned to prepare for strong winds, rain and ice leading to flooding as the country is battered for a second day by Storm Barra. Gales and snow blizzards caused chaos on Tuesday with wind gusts reaching mph at Aberdaron, in Gwynedd, while around , homes in north-east Scotland, Northern Ireland and Wales lost power.Now dozens of flood warnings have been issued across the UK along with the Met Office also issuing a yellow weather warning of gales in England for Wednesday.The Environment Agency has issued  flood warnings for England at locations including Hartlepool and Sunderland in the North East, Bournemouth and Weymouth in the South, and part of the Cumbrian coast. Some  flood alerts, for areas where flooding is possible, have also been issued across the country.  The Scottish Environment Protection Agencyhas sent  flood alerts and five warnings for areas in the north-east of Scotland and the south-west. Natural Resources Wales has also issued  flood warnings and  alerts, mainly covering coastal areas. Properties may flood and there may be travel disruption, said the Environment Agency. Local river and surface water flooding is also possible for parts of England and Wales on Tuesday and Wednesday. Land and roads may flood and there may be travel disruption.  More chaos comes as communities in the North East and Scotland are still trying to recover from the catastrophic effects of Storm Arwen. Thousands of homes lost power for up to  days in the wake of mph winds and lashing rain at the end of November. Northern Powergrid has not confirmed whether all homes were connected by Tuesday night as promised.Storm Barra moved in from the west on Tuesday, and a yellow weather warning for wind is in place from midnight until pm on Wednesday for the west coast of Wales and south-west England. As well as the high winds that hit Gwynedd, North Wales, which is covered by the wind warning, Orlock Head in Co Down, Northern Ireland Ireland, faced mph gusts on Tuesday. Met Office forecasters said Storm Barra may not cause as much chaos as Storm Arwen – though it has already sparked travel delays and school closures in Scotland. Spokeswoman Nicky Maxey said: “We are not expecting the impacts of Barra to be as bad as we saw with Arwen. “Storm Barra will bring strong winds and heavy rainfall to many parts of the UK today. We may see some snow on the higher ground, too. “It is unlikely to be as impactful as Storm Arwen last week but there will be blustery conditions so people should still be prepared.” ScotRail has warned that some Wednesday services will be cancelled due to the storm. The strong winds is expected to mean the temperatures are milder than usual for the time of year on Wednesday, with London predicted to see C, C in Cardf, C for Edinburgh and C in Belfast. Boris Johnson said on Monday more than , homes were still without power but that he was assured by Northern Powergrid boss Phil Jones that “affected properties would be reconnected on Tuesday at the latest.  The Prime Minister said “too many people have spent too long without power” and the situation in northern England was not acceptable. Schools in Dumfries and Galloway were forced to close because of the weather. Stranraer Academy was shut after the wind caused structural damage to the roof, the council said, and Drummore School closed after trees were blown down. UK forecast for the next  days Today: A generally windy day, with early gales in the west and southwest, perhaps severe in coastal Wales. Showers affecting most areas, some heavy and with some more persistent bands of showery rain especially across Wales. A little brightness or sunshine. Tonight: Showery rain and showers easing for many, clearer spells allowing patchy frost, mostly in the north. However parts of northwest England and the northwest Midlands likely to keep some showers. Thursday: Showers continuing to ease away northeastwards, many parts fine for a time. Rain ing to western parts by afternoon and central areas later. Mostly fairly chilly, milder in southwest later. Outlook for Friday to Sunday: Drier weather at times, with unsettled interludes. Blustery showers Friday and Sunday, mainly for the north and west, with longer spells of rain for most through Saturday. Turning milder.
